Significantly mor up market than Venice beach, better food, less freaks and less drugs, a great pier.
This pier is a standard tacky place with all the things that you might expect from a Blackpool type place with sun. No class and little to hold your interest.The walk along the beach is lovely.
Good look for a first time, however it is very crowded.Good place to people watch.Food is a bit limited so if your hungry, best to head up into Santa Monica.

column2: The last place to be in Santa Monica
column3: This place is a tourist trap, very crowded, subpar shopping and food. There are so many good things to do in Santa Monica that i will recommend to leave this as your last.

Really beautiful beach - you can just chill on the beach sunbathing, go on the observation wheel (which is solar powered - so cool) or watch various groups working out at the original muscle beach - alternatively you can hire bikes pretty cheap and cycle down to Venice beach for a change of scenery!!

column2: Long layover at LAX, so we explore
column3: With a long layover at LAX we rented a car and went for a drive. Santa Monica was on the list as a place you could visit and still make it back for our flight. The pier is the end of route 66 which we did not know at the time. So that's an added smile on your face when you find that out. We strolled the pier and did some people watching. Also got to see some fishermen catch some fish. As a fisherman myself I was really surprised at the fish cleaning stations on the pier. With running water. My guess is that the dumping of the fish guts helps to bring more fish in, like a chum log would. Ar restaurant at the end of the pier had sine good views for the dinners. Because they blocked off anyone from fishing in front of the Windows. Which I think is fare. No-one wants to be eating dinner and not be able to see the beach. There are many little cats selling art and tee shirts. An arcade for the kids to sirens some money in playing the boardwalk games. I think if your in the area you should take some time for a walk on the pier at Santa Monica.

We stayed in Santa Monica over New Year 2015-16 and spent a good few hours on the pier. I loved Zoltar (please tell me you've seen "Big"?!) and the end of the pier; my boyfriend loved the route 66 facts and Bubba Gump (unfortunately we didn't eat there this trip, next time!). The pier is iconic, historic and emotive; you can't help but realise the feet that have come before and will follow after. I can't wait to be there again.

We booked tickets online, with a small discount to the Pacific Park on the pier. The attractions/rides are more geared to young children or teens, but we enjoyed ourselves, being slightly older. It was the Labour Day Monday, so there were wall to wall people along the pier, so it was a bit chaotic, but fun nonetheless
We came from the high desert on a day trip to enjoy the Ocean view, it was a lovely day with plenty of street performers to look at. We will come again.

The water was SUPER cold, but that didn't stop my 7 and 9 yr old boys and the rest of the people...LOL!. It was such a great place to just sit out and enjoy the sun. The attractions were a nice addition as well as the street artist with great talent. I'm from the East Coast, so I enjoyed Cali's summer heat....no humidity whatsoever!
The pier was beautiful and you must walk up into town for the great shopping. The downtown and pier has free street wifi. Lots of Pokemon catching for my kids. We really enjoyed this outing.

column2: A fun place to spend the afternoon
column3: Strolling around the pier one afternoon after a business conference adjourned was a lot of fun. There was an obvious police presence, so there was absolutely no shenanigans. There are lots of souvenir shops and restaurants. Make sure you ride the ferris wheel and take the kids to the carnival.

column2: lots of cool shops, rides, street musicians, food - something for everyone
column3: came here as part of our venice beach boardwalk cruise -- it's about 2 miles north. nice walk to and from along the beach. the pier is very cool with all the usual accoutrements you'd expect to see -- the street musicians displaying their talents and offering CDs for sale, restaurants to meet everyone's tastes, amusement park rides, the ocean to stare at, the people... perfect for a stroll at any time of day.
Visited this beach before going to the airport and it was so beautiful I didn't want to leave. Clean fresh and pretty.

column2: Nice few hours in the sun
column3: Very clean pier. Easy to get to on the Hop On Hop Off bus route. Theres pleanty of food and drink places and the fairground. Take your flip flops! The sand is very hot!

Did not love the pier. It was just okay. It felt very commercial to me. The highlight was seeing "Zoltar" from the movie BIG. It was busy. There were a lot of people and a very strong police presence. The beach is beautiful and the area is nicely kept. Just did not find it exciting or very interesting. It is however, a beautiful spot to watch the sunset!
Pleasant atmosphere and a variety of attractions on the pier. Nice bars and restaurants nearby. Nice day out.

The pier was packed with people but the views of the Pacific were nice. Some restaurants and stores but mostly tourist trap type places. Lots of musicians playing and some artists selling their wares. Pay to play rides and carnival games for the kids. Parking was packed but several lots available around the area. Most surprising was the abundance of clean bathrooms. I would love to visit when not so crowded. It think it would be a better experience.

Were made here...I grew up in la. Technically I'm a valley girl but spent most of my teen years on the other side exploring Hollywood and venice on foot. The pier is so beautiful and so much fun. Just be careful after dark if you aren't familiar with the area. Kk? Or at least ladies please don't walk around at by yourself.
A good place to spend a lazy evening stroll or just sitting by the bench behind the Ferris wheel facing the ocean. Stop by Route 66 marker.

It's nice. Something you need to see on your trip!It is very crowded and touristy. Very over priced.We had a great time nonetheless.Try to avoid Friday nights and weekends as it's very packed, could barely move down the pier, felt like sardines!!!
Just a bunch of restaurants packed in a pear as if it means to spoil the mood and scenery of the wide beach ..

column2: Nice to have been there, but I won't return
column3: Crowded with loads of tourists, if you visit in summer. Plain and trashy, unless you visit off season. Beggars

Took three teens an a ten year old to experience the pier, although it was a fun day out we did feel the wrist bands were a bit pricey for the amount of rides on offer.Beach is obviously beautiful as are the views from the end of the pier.Parking was easy, close by and cheap.
A small piece of happiness in front of the stunning ocean. A never ending beach, restaurants, artists, great people watching. A must see in LA

Santa monica beach / amazing beach specially the sunset. We saw abeautiful bridge thousands of people visiting. I loved the souvonires and i saw avery famous street (the 3rd street ) / amazing shoppings and shows and restaurants.
Great place to walk around, eat or ride a few rides. Parking is available but could be an issue if the lot is full.

column2: Started out as a short stroll.
column3: The Santa Monica Pier held a couple of surprises. The first was the discovery that it is the end of Route 66. Something we are going to travel in near future. The other surprise was the numerous views from the pier.

Visited over Labor Day weekend when it was swarming with people plus the Pokemon hunters...the close by parking lots were full at 10:30 am but we parked at the civic lot near the courthouse and only paid $4 for several hours...crowded, touristy and great people watching..Something fun for everyone...

column2: Nice views, good place to see
column3: This is a free area to visit with very accessible and cheap parking so well worth a visit. Nice views, interesting to walk around for an hour

It may be famous, it may be a national treasure, it may attract thousands of people.....but, to me, it was crowded (OK it was Labor Day), almost impossible to move in places, and, frankly tawdry.There were buskers, evangelists, hawkers, tacky stalls with souvenirs, and quite a bit of emphasis on the fact that this was the end of the old Route 66 (a lot of the t-shirts and caps made reference to this in their logos.Hey, this is pretty negative - sorry. So.... a rather pleasant carousel, great place to people watch, excellent views of the beautiful beach and ocean, good for families. Check!

This place is cool, very iconic, but that's all. It's beautiful to see, hard to walk on due to the people traffic so it's hard to review. I loved seeing it, had fun here but it's just so busy and expensive. I barged into a lot of people, on purpose too, because they're just so ignorant and won't move, especially the Pokemon players.The famous "end of Route 66" sign is cool. The food is expensive, Pacific park is expensive, the boardwalk is always busy even at night time, the beach is right there and very very busy. It's a good place for people watching and hearing a variety of live music.Parking at the pier is about $12 a day and of course it's busy! The spaces are also very tight, not somewhere you want to take a large car.
It's beautiful there, romantic, lots of restaurants. We really enjoyed our time, if you're in LA, definitely go to Santa Monica!

After many years of wanting to visit the Santa Monica Pier we finally went. It was worth the wait. Beautiful pier, beach and amusement park, Pacific Park. Lots of entertainment at the pier. We saw seals. Muscle park was interesting to watch. Lots to do.
It was hard for me to experience much because it was so crowded you could barely walk. I'm sure it would have been better had there not been so any people.
This place is super chill with a really nice atmosphere to walk around. Beware of a million Pokemon players though.
My family and I love this place and come and least once a year but you do have to get there early to find close parking

column2: Wow. What a crowd. But a must see
column3: We went on labour Monday and it was standing room only. But really worth the visit with the electric atmosphere.Remember to get a churro when you are there.

A landmark sign beckons you onto the pier, which has a few restaurants, a beautiful enclosed carousel which Clint Eastwood featured in one of his movies, plus the amusement park. The Ferris wheel has a self-powered LED lighting system that is quite spectacular at night. The views from the pier are also lovely.

column2: Fun but A Lot Of People!!
column3: Recently went with some friends and our two-year-old. Definitely a great people watching place. We loved all the musicians playing along the pier and bought one of their CDs. We also enjoyed the outdoor rides. Parking can be crazy and there's a lot of people. We found that you need to have cash to pay for parking and that it's best to go in the morning to get a spot.

column2: Let's soak up some sun and people watch
column3: People watching at its finest...the pier is typically super busy at least every time that I have visited. Plenty of snack stands and performers alike and if your bold enough you can ride one of the rides

Awesome food, great view, easily accessible... and WOW.. the "performance art" (random folks bringing out mics, guitars, drums,...) is very entertaining to say the least.Go for a short walk and maybe some food, be prepared to people watch - this is some of the best people watching you will ever see.
Sunset at the pier is beyond words.It's a touristy place with souvenir shops on the pier and boardwalk.Fun place to bring kids.Ok food.

Love this place it's full of interesting characters and is a really unique place. There is something for everyone from food outlets, shopping, street entertainment and even the iconic big wheel. So much to do and see but I enjoyed sitting on a bench watching the sea listening to one of the many music artists performing.Visit at night as well for a completely different vibe.Also a hub for Pokemon hunters as there was hundreds of people walking around with their phones in front of their faces, which was a funny sight to see!

column2: Great view of the Pacific Ocean
column3: A nice spot at the end of Rt 66. The Ferris Wheel is a must for the view of the beach. It is a tourist destination, but for good reason.

column2: Santa Monica and Labor Day weekend
column3: Go early for parking!! On holidays this beautiful beach gets PACKED! I'm talking about detours, full parking lots and 1-2 hour drives that normally take 10-15 minutes. Over all the wait and 4 mile walk back and forth to the pier was freakin worth it! This beach has something for everyone!üíó
All I can say this is one beautiful place lots of things to do if you're single or have a family you're sure to have a ball.
Forest Gump bench, nice view of Venice Beach and Santa Monica. the best Ice Cream in town. lovely place just to sit and enjoy the view of Ocean.

It's fun to see the ocean but the whole pier begs the question '"Why?"What was fun in yesteryear isn't really that interesting anymore and the place is super crowded. I'd skip it. Walk the beach instead.
A must do for 1st time visitors - just to say you were there. Would I go back? no. but it's a great photo opp on a sunny day!

Santa Monica, one of my favourite places! The pier is fun and a great place to hang out in the sun. Just a few steps and you can chill on the clean and litter free beach or walk along the sea edge. If you are in the area ...visit this beautiful beautiful place.
We hired bicycles from J's cycle hire on Venice beach, $6/hour and cycled to the pier and back. There'sa flat cycle path and it's great just for people watching.
We visited it at night.. The breeze was nice.. Had a nice meal at Bubba Gump.. A nice place to stroll.. The lights and ambience gives a certain kind of charm..

column2: Lots of homeless folks - over hyped
column3: Lots of beggars, homeless folks bothering you and when telling them you'd like to be left alone they get very angry. Rides are pricey. Nice if you like this but nothing special.

column2: Definitely don't go on the weekend
column3: We went as a stop over on our way to Disneyland. It was so overly crowded it was impossible to even get food. The people there were rude and really ruined the experience for us. I can imagine that if it were less crowded it would be a fun walk and interesting to see but we won't be going back
We were disappointed with the Santa Monica Pier. It's very touristy and has tacky shops. There are some restaurants, but we did not eat in them.
Visited Labor Day Saturday....too many people, horrible restaurant options near pier and not that clean. Did not check out rides, as looked cheap. Great people watching though.

Ehhh wasn't overly impressed. Everyone told me to come here but when I arrived it was night and seemed like there were 10 million people! So make sure you like crowds!! I walked up and down, got bored and left.

column2: An Absolute Must when visiting Santa Monica
column3: The Santa Monica pier is a landmark destination for those visiting Santa Monica.It has a plethora of entertainment, restaurants and picturesque views of Santa Monica beach.In addition, Pacific Park (an amusement park on the pier) is an incredible attraction for all ages.

Lovely setting, fun pier with good facilities. For anyone from the UK it is a typical pier with fun fair, restaurants, shops, something we are sadly loosing in the UK. Bubba Gump Shrimp is a great place to eat, but you may need to book.
I walked here from Venice beach. The rides loomed pretty fun even though I didn't ride anymore. There were some cool street performers and the pier has some great views.

We rid5e the ferris wheel which provided great views. We shared a Japadog...which is a Japanese hot dog. It was pretty tasty. We saw a few strange things. Shopping was close by and we stopped in at Lulu Lemon.

Very busy pier and I mean very busy in August, lots of things going on with music acts, free lemonade promotions and then there is the fun fair. It was a flying visit so didn't have time to buy the wrist bands and queue for the rides but still good none the less.

After parking up in Venice Beach and walking round there for a while, we set off walking up to Santa Monica. Around 1.7 miles. Got to say it's like leaving a 3rd world country and walking into luxury. What a difference. The beach, the town and of course the pier itself were amazing. Always wanted to come here after watching The Lost Boys all those years ago. The rides and games are all worth a go.
A great place for an afternoon stroll. A fun place, on the beach, with rides and shops and stalls. It's far from modern which is endearing in Santa Monica!

This is a fun place in an iconic location. The views across the beaches and the ocean are fab. The pier is bustling with activity with lots of things to see an do. We ate on the pier and then took a stroll around, but then left as the heat of the day got the better of us, however, there is lots to see and do, including some amusements and a fun fair.The kids will have a great time.

Here is great parking on pier near theme park The Overlook on the ocean on the tip of the pier is great nice view Sunset is the best and watch out for sand crabs if you don't know what they are Google them they're everywhere LOL
Great walking visit to a wonderful pier. There is a mex restaurant at the end of the pier which is fantastic, as well.

column2: I expected more but definitely a must see.
column3: Being from Sydney, with drawing the obvious comparisons, I don't understand the hype. An average beach with an average setting, the pier is overcrowded and more so at night. Don't get me wrong, it's worth a visit however is pretty average.

The pier itself is great with the amusement park and plenty of restaurants to choose from. Even on a busy day it's possible to find a quite little area to yourself if you wish. Street musicians play all along the pier and there are plenty of little stalls offering souvenirs to take home. The walk along the beach from the pier is beautiful also with some stunning properties lining the beach. The 'beach gym' is also a great place to watch people learning new skills like slack lining etc
At last we saw the famous Santa Monica Pier..fun place, arcades and rides..worth a visit...nice view of Malibu from the pier.

column2: Amusement park on the ocean, what's not to like!
column3: Street performers, arcade games, and carnival rides taking you out over the ocean makes the Santa Monica Pier a true destination stop on the So Cal ocean front. If you can't find some fun here, (great people watching spot), then you have missed the whole point of the area. Take some time, ride the rides, and toss a few quarters to one or two of the performers and enjoy a sunny California day on the pier.
Just simply a great place to visit. Iconic! The atmosphere was so peaceful and pleasant to experience. If you go to the LA/Santa Monica area, this is a must see!

Before I went to LA, I was advised to go to Santa Monica Pier. That it is a must see/experience.Was it just overhyped for me? Or was it really just not as great as people told me?Any tourist should still come here but once you get there it could be a little underwhelming.Don't get me wrong, I still enjoyed this place. But I was really disappointed as it didn't give me the excitement that everyone gave me when they told me about this place.Beautiful pacific coast though. But you can see that all along PCH.
Great for a stroll amount the tourist tat and take in the sea air. The beaches are fabulous and the fun fair is, well, fun

We got an Uber out and had a wander around on a Thursday afternoon. We then walked down to Venice Beach that took about 20mins.Santa Monica is very clean and lots of shops before you get onto the pier. The pier itself has loads of side shows, buskers, rides and the restaurant at the end.√úber from West Hollywood cost us $9 in a shared ride.Would be cool to go at night time when all the lights would be on the pier.Take cash & 1-2hours. We just wandered around in 20mins the left for Venice. But if you did rides and things would need longer.

column2: Pretty crazy and over the top
column3: A visual overload at night but part of the fun of being so close. A must see just for the experience of a true boardwalk.

Location, Location, Location. It does not get any better than the beaches in Santa Monica. However, this carnival could use an upgrade. The rides are fine for little kids, but even they get bored after a couple of hours of this place. I suggest going early when the park opens, but not at night time on the weekend, it is very crowded, unless of course, you like crowds.

column2: Would like to have stayed longed
column3: I went to Santa Monica Pier as part of a day trip to LA from Las Vegas. Thinking about it now it wasn't the greatest idea as we spent more time driving than we did actually walking around.Even though we didn't get to stay long we still had enough time to look around the souvenir shops, have a wander round the fairground and get something to eat. Was a little disappointed I didn't have enough time to eat in Bubba Gumps though as that's a favourite of mine.Considering it was obviously busy everything was clean and tidy which would make me want to return to take advantage of the lovely beach.The only downside is the parking but we were lucky enough to be dropped off but I think you would have had a long wait to find a space so probably advisable to get there early.
Rather you spend time at the beach or at the pier you will be sure to have a good time. Parking is a bit expensive and a hassle otherwise we enjoyed it

We visited to signify the end of our Route 66 trip. Parking is $12 so expensive. The pier is nice for a quick walk. A lot of the shops on the pier are touristy.Santa Monica itself is very nice, the pier just seems a bit tacky
Not horrible, but not much of an amusement park. Just a few rides, the usual fast food, an arcade, etc. Pleasant and clean. OK if your expectations aren't high.

Stayed opposite the pier and gave up trying to get on it on a Saturday evening, it was heaving! Went back Sunday morning around 7.30 am it was lovely, hardly any crowds and the views are amazing. Just steer clear of all the Pokemon hunters!

The best time to visit the Pier is at night. Its pretty spectacular to see the pier come alive at night with the different lights. The area is a huge tourist attraction. Shopping and eating with a view of the ocean is unbeatable. Highly recommend. Drive around to find cheaper parking.
Lovely old fashion pier with a few places to buy a treat or two it gets VERY busy during the summer months but still a nice walk around.Beautiful at sunset.

column2: Nice for a walk any time of day
column3: This area is very touristy but has some charm thanks to the wooden pier. It offers nice views and foods any time of day or evening. Good for meeting people/ going out and also for pokemon hunting !

column2: route 66 end of the trail sign
column3: We walked along the sea front trail from Marina Del Rey to the Santa Monica pier to see the Route 66 sign and the end of the trail, which is actually sign posted on the pier itself.The beach and pier section of Santa Monica got very busy with visitors from all over the world. With all the bikes and cars parked up that have done the Route 66 tour all the way from Chicago.The pier has a show ground on it as well as people fishing and people entertaining the crowds.We even had our friend the sea lion waiting for us at the end of the pier.

This ‚ÄúIconic Jewel‚Äù of the Pacific Coast still has its Ferris wheel, its Carousel, and the Pacific Park Amusement Rides. Visiting it last month brought back memories from 35 years ago when we came here for the first time.The place was jam-packed with tourists, street performers, and people glued to their phones collecting Pokemon. There were even more souvenir shops, food stands and people playing live music than we remember from last time.Still, the vibe is friendly, jolly and fun for young and old alike. This time we noticed the sign that states that ‚ÄúRoute 66 Ends Here‚Äù, and naturally, we had to pose under it.The Ferris wheel provides a fabulous back-drop for pictures for one of the most visited places in this State. It is such a recognizable Pier, since it is seen in many movies and also on TV.For us, the place was too crowded, and the Beach was not clean, but the weather was warm, the views were outstanding, and the people all around us were super friendly. So we have no hesitation in recommending a visit, just for the fun of it.

column2: Good place to see some sights
column3: We went on the pier and had funnel cake which was not really a funnel but was unite tasty for all the family. Best food and entertainment was just off the pier
Well worth a visit for a bit of nostalgia combined with some great views of the Pacific. The weekdays are quieter and the beach is really nice.

If you've never been there I guess it's worth going once just to say hey I went to Santa Monica but it's not really a big deal if you don't mind crowds then go it's crazy that you have to pay that much to park to really see nothing. GODISLOVE

This was our first time in California. We were there for a week. It was more so a Disneyland trip with other days sprinkled in between. The pier was beautiful. We didn't ride and of the rides, we played Pokemon GO and the PoGO scene there is crazy good! We enjoyed the beautiful beach, like it was beautiful. I am so in love with California now and specifically Santa Monica that I asked my husband if we could move there.

After a meal has a stroll along the famous Santa Monica pier to find the route 66 start sign seeing as we were embarking on this trip. There was a chap in a kiosk who was very knowledgeable and very helpful. We loved the sights and my daughter did a couple of rides. Too many people doing this silly pokemon hunt thing which was ridiculous to see grown adults running around with their phone's . Definitely worth a visit.

This tourist attraction is perfectly viewed from afar. I was there on a Saturday, so I'm sure it's extra busy on the weekends, but single file walking is not my thing. It reminded me of a typical weekend fair or carnival but with a much better view.

This was our first time to Santa Monica Pier, Great Garage parking close to the pier, the walk was a little much back up the ramp. Overall the experience was wonderful, watched the surfers off the pier, Volleyball games, especially liked the brazilian game were no hands can be used, that is talent. The theme park, has offerings for children , young adults and adults. Bubba Gumps shrimp restaurant was one of the dining establishments on the pier. The real disappointment was the aquarium not what we expected at all. A few fish tanks? in and out in less than 15 minutes. We stayed in Newport Beach, visiting Santa Monica pier was worth the drive. It is very crowded on a Saturday.

column2: It's a must see if you are in California
column3: It's a must see if you come to California, the view and the sunsets are unbelievable, it's nice to take a ride down to the Pacific coast!
We went before sunset. Quite a busy place.Worth the visit if only to Brag that you have been there.Good for some nice holiday souvenir pictures.
Sadly the pier had no real attractiveness and nothing special to it. Some fast food restaurants and couple of rides.Wouldn't bother again.

We don't have to go far to get to the pier from where we stay, so not sure how I'd rate it as a destination. It's basically a bunch of cheesy rides and shops overlooking the Pacific Ocean. You can get to the beach from here and there's a cute tiny aquarium and a nice carousel. What else is there to say? We rent bikes from a shop just behind the pier, on occasion, get a hot dog on a stick and a lemknade, etc. It's fun for an afternoon. And on weekends it's thronged if you're into people-watching.

We travelled into Santa Monica just after rush hour, we purposely avoided the week end as its too busy.We arrived around 10:30 am, no waiting to park, the pier wasn't crowded, strolled, shopped and enjoyed the view.We found it to be nothing more than a small theme park with an ocean view. Kids would love it.

column2: It is good for what it is.
column3: I did not know that this was the historical end of Route 66!! Learnt something new, Paradise Pier has a little theme park, nothing but expensive if you do not buy the wrist band. Good for all ages. I bet it looks really nice at night when all the lights are one. The pier is as expected old and I got a few splinters in my feet even when I wearing my flip flops. The nails holding down the wooden battens jut out, so be careful as I tripped up on them a couple of times, also watch your phones as they will be lost forever if they fall between the gaps. We ate at the "famous hotdog," place, nope!! They were horrible to taste and they take ages before your order is ready. It is fairly pricey here, the average t-shirt is around $30 plus tax. The views are amazing though, the actual beach was dirty, with hidden broken bottles, bottle caps and other rubbish, so wear some sort of footwear. We also did the redline tour of stars homes. Honestly, it is much better to take in the view of the coastline. I for one thought it was quite instrusive to drive right up to various famous people's homes and see if they were in, pointing out their actual address and what car they drove. I wasn't impressed personally. The pier and the beach stole the show. We took the expo line direct from 7th and metro, really easy direct line and cost a couple of dollars each way for us all. The metro stops literally a few hundred yards way from the beach. What more could you ask for.
Santa Monica Pier is what dreams are made of. The vibe, culture, people, music, food, views...the list could go on! There is honestly nothing quite like Santa Monica Pier in the world!

column2: Amusement Park right in Downtown Santa Monica
column3: It is almost a throwback to another era -- a classic amusement park on a pier located right in downtown Santa Monica. It has the classic amusement park rides, including a wonderful merry-go-round. Fun during the day and great at night when they turn on the lights. It is always crowded but everyone seemed to have a good time.

column2: Tacky isn't always a bad thing
column3: Like any other seaside pier, this has amusements arcades, tasteless souvenir shops and a pervading smell of fried food. Don't be put off though, because it's safe, interesting a window on life. Some of the live music played at the end of the pier was excellent.
I advise the people who likes beaches to visit other beaches in los angeles city or in orange county .The third st near the santa monica pier is cool and alot of street musicians there.

Visited in the peak of summer and had an absolutely fantastic time!The pier is an incredibly busy attraction and it took us over 10 mins just to walk down onto the pier because there was so many people about.It's a great site though, beautiful views and the Mexican restaurant at the end of the pier is incredible!Overall we spent a fun afternoon at the pier and enjoying the beaches surrounding. I would definitely visit again.
Fun to see and it provided a neat photo opportunity but really nothing else. And of course it's crowded with lots and lots of people. But the beach next to the pier is great!

The pier itself is free to visit. But, there are several things that cost money on the pier. We enjoyed people watching and looking at the views. There are plenty of shops and restaurants along the pier. It is a great place to hang out for an afternoon of fun in the sun.

U could easily spend a few hours here. Lots of games, rides and food joints. The kids had the day wrist band, it's very worth it; u pay around 17USD and the kids can go and use any ride unlimited times. Great pictures here

Awesome place to hang out for the day with an array of activities - view out in the pier, play some games or go on rides at Pacific Park, cool off at the beach, good souvenir shopping and street entertainment.
It's kept in good condition, fun stuff to do for kids and has some restaurants.Highlight for us was the evening walk at sunset and in the night.Recommend to go!

My wife and I were biking down the beach, and we stopped at the pier to get lunch. It's a great place to walk around for a couple of hours. There are many food options from sit down restaurants to walk up burger joints. There's also an amusement park on the pier with a roller coaster, Ferris wheel, and some other games. Great view of the beach and the mountains surrounding the pier. Highly recommend.

If you have kids then they will totally enjoy the small amusement park there and if you are into shopping there are couple of stores there for souvenirs and beach wear. And if you are into photography then it's the perfect stop. I guess the place fits everybody

I was thrilled to visit the iconic Santa Monica pier. It looks nothing like the scene in Forrest Gump although there is a Bubba Gump restaurant there.It was a Saturday evening when we visited, the peak of crowds and activities there. There was live music playing, an arcade, and tons of places to eat. But you get that at shore locations all over the place. What is cool here is to look over and see the glow of sunset to the north. I love the way a long boardwalk zone stretches out to sea instead of parallel to it.No trip to Santa Monica is complete without a visit to the Pier. It is the west coast equivalent to the Asbury Park Boardwalk with all the symbolic, historic, and cultural meaning both entail.

We had a fun few days here! The best bet is to get a wristband at the pier as the tickets to rides pricy. You have to go here if you are visiting LA with kids. So campy and they will love it. I feel you need to just adopt a SOCAL attitude and roll with whatever while here- weed, homelessness, lots of dogs, lots of sale pitches etc. But no one will really bug you. And if you give someone some food or water- why not? We loved it here. The beach was hot and the water refreshing. Overall a great time!
A fun stroll even when it looks crowded. Once you're on the pier you'll find it's not soooo crowded.
When a week ago. The pier is full of gift shops and places to eat but at high prices. We spent the morning there. A definitely beatyfull morning.

column2: Of Course You Have To See It
column3: My family and I came to Los Angeles 10 years ago and the Santa Monica Pier was one of our favorite memories. I wanted to bring my daughter back to see it now that she was a young adult. There is something so special about standing on that pier and seeing the beach below and the homes on the hill behind you. The pier itself can be crowded depending on the time of day, but is certainly worth the walk to the end just to catch a view of the coastline. If you like amusement parks, there is one right on the pier. We were not up for it this time, especially not when we saw a fairly long line to ride the ferris wheel. There were some great musicians playing on the pier, so make sure to stop and listen. Some have real talent and draw a crowd. Naturally, you must get a photo of yourself in front of the iconic Santa Monica Pier sign!

The view of the ocean is breathtaking. Plus the walk along the pier is long and invigorating. Crab a coffee as its a bit chilly in winter but do walk right till the very end. On your way back stop at the restaurant called Baba Gump! Is got good food and quite fun for a forest Gump fan!

Just a fun place to go enjoy sun and the sounds of the ocean. The little amusement park is so fun and the Peir offers decent food options. The energy is good and people are in good spirits. I love this place.
coming from new York it's a different lifestyle. there was something about this pier that made it so different. go on the ferris üé° wheel . nice place to take pictures

column2: Great nostalgic trip to the coast
column3: Great summer feel good location, old school fair ground attractions and great views.Head to the beach front and enjoy the buskers, street vendors, local characters, food and bars to really make the most of your trip.Well worth a visit!
Great place....but like all the great places, we always have peddlers and homeless drunks sleeping everywhere at any time of the day.It is California at its best.

We went to the pier for a quick lunch break before heading to observatory in LA. Bubba Gump at the start of the pier is a great option for lunch and very family friendly. Lovely views from the end of pier both over the sea and coastline. Parking right next to pier only $12 for the day.

column2: Good mix of food, colors and ocean
column3: We rented bikes from Venice beach and decided to walk the pier. Good break, many food and sitin options. Great location for iconic picture taking. At the end, view of ocean and cool breeze are just the thing to relax. Overall, great location for stroll
Definitely a must see if you are in California. Lots of different things to see all kinds of people.

I never do activities like this in my own home town, but in SoCal, this was a delightful experience. Many, many tourists and cheesy shops. But, absolutely worth the trip on your first visit to Santa Monica.

column2: Fun on the beach and pier
column3: Beautiful beach and not too crowded. we all headed straight into the water. First time in the Pacific and FHD temperature was amazing. Waves fairly strong, knocked you off your feet but great fun. A nice walk on the pier with lunch ended a fab trip.
Great for a few hours wandering. Iconic landmark. Lots to see live music, we saw a seal which was lovely.

We rented 2 bikes for just over an hour and cycled from Venice to Santa Monica Pier and back. It was early morning and quiet (although alot of homeless around). It's a pleasant cycle and worth doing. The Pier itself is pretty and good for the photo opportunities. A nice way to see the Venice/Santa Monica beaches.
Great way to spend time with family, fun food & great place to Pok√©mon hunt :)I suggest parking in the beach lot and walking the quarter mile to the pier.
Santa Monica pier did not disappoint. Great views and so many interesting characters! The rides area was well maintained.

personally, i did not take the rides but it definitely added colours on the beach.... everyone is happy! there are security officers and a post right at the pier, safety is good. There is a food kiosk right at the theme park entrance!

Went in the summer and it was incredibly crowded and full of tourists (including us!)The good restaurants were not on the pier, and the pier was filled with the usual touristy stuff. The beach itself was overcrowded.Worth briefly checking out - great views - but wouldn't spend much time.
Visited Santa Monica Pier last week!Its beautiful. Not too many stores to get souvenirs but the ones they have I'm sure you'll find something! Ferris wheel is very nice too. Lots of entertainment

For a British audience, this can best be compared to Barry Island or Blackpool. In short, a tacky, expensive dump. It is a beautiful stretch of coastline, totally spoiled by a massive parking lot and a tacky pier with amusements and rides. Sad. To quote Joni Mitchell, "They paved Paradise to put up a parking lot."
Better beach than other beaches. Nice shops too... Evening time is good to spend there. Must see beach in Los Angeles

column2: It's nice for a days trip
column3: I come from Ohio, so this was a culture shock for me. The pier is nice, great view, a must see if your traveling and has everything you expect while traveling. Tons of people (don't plan on running or walking fast from about 10 am until about 10 pm) Don't try and drive and park, just take an Uber or taxi. Save your self the hassle. Everything is way over priced in my opinon, but that's a matter of opinion. We did not do the rides or arcade, but it reminds me of those pop up fairs that come to town :/ so not my cup of tea. The beach is nice and was clean while we were there!The only problem is the homeless and/or beggers around. It's something that shocked me coming to LA. I didn't know how bad it was. They sleep everywhere and anywhere so if your an early morning beach runner expect to see them on the beach sleeping. They are harmless it seems, just ignore them if they get loud and enjoy your trip :) it was something that shocked me though about the pier.

column2: Fun for tourists, but parking and traffic are an issue
column3: Can't beat a day on the pier...or night for that matter. Just make sure you park far enough away to avoid gridlock of downtown SM.

Great way to spend a 14 hour layover at LAX. Quick ride (15 minutes) to the pier. Enjoyed several talented artists playing live music; a lively/happy atmosphere; ferris wheel overlooking the ocean, beach, pier; people watching....just so much to see and do. We were treated to playful sea lions flirting with the crowd then diving out of view. The ferris wheel offered beautiful views of the pier, mountains & ocean. Vendors politely great tourists with a variety of souvenir offerings. Even the police with surf boards strapped to their SUV were a fun photo op. Highly recommend a visit to gain a flair for this region.
Santa Monica pier is so beautiful. Small booths where people are selling homemade stuff. A lot of carousels, specifically the ferris wheel is very famous and nice. Beautiful vibe and great people.

column2: Very nice at nighttime - Crowded in summer
column3: The ferris wheel has gorgeous lights at night. Loved watching it. We visited in Aug 2016, so it was super packed! Parking wasn't good either, so we had to walk a long ways on empty stomachs. Restaurants were mostly booked, but luckily we found some food without a wait (Rusty's Surf Ranch). The rides looked very busy, but I do want to go back someday.
Let is be Summer, Winter or Spring this place is the best spot to spend your weekends! Let it be for dining, shopping or just lay on the sand next to the pier and enjoy the sun.
Stopped real quick just to see it and was entertained by the entertainment and the guys fishing off the end of the pier.

column2: Tourist location that everyone needs to visit
column3: As a middle aged gal, this pier brought back great childhood memories when the carnival was in town ...Fun rides for kids and the Ferris Wheel gives you great views of the region.
It's fun to visit here but parking is a pain and expensive. Also prices are high for things on pier. Fun to people watch and watch ocean.

This place is packed on weekends and parking lots can get full....quick. We parked at the Sears lot when you first come in...which may or may not have been a good choice...its expensive ($25) compared to some of the other lots ($15)...but on the other hand, I didn't drive around for an hour trying to find a lot with an opening.
This place is beautiful and very entertaining. Watching the sunset was probably the best part about the pier besides the Ferris wheel.

Santa Monica is an iconic jewel on the pacific coast of Los Angeles. CA.It's pier, on the beautiful and often visited waterfront deserves to bea place of entertainment, interest, and, at least, lasting memory.IT IS NOT. The few shops offer shallow, junk tourist fare. The slimdining offerings are lower than street carnival fare. The once proudCarousel, with live vintage Calliope, now has recorded music.Santa Monica can, and must do better!

column2: Nice place to Have Fun in Santa Monica
column3: This place is Fune For Grups or Cuples Is Smaall but CoolI love to go ther by Summer Time.After 5 pm is perfect to watch the Suncet
It was a nice walk down the pier. I got sun burned, but should have expected that. Silly me. After being inside most of the week, a long stroll down the pier was perfect.
Visited from Wisconsin. People watching was fun. We also got to watch a seal swimming around the pier. Stopped for a beer and burger on the boardwalk.

column2: Brings you back to your childhood!
column3: The Ferris wheel provided the most magical view of the coast line and the water. The pier itself had all the carnival games to compete for a prize from back in the day. Relaxing ride on the wheel, great photo ops. So many other rides to enjoy. Transforms you back to your youth.

column2: Very crowded but good place to start a bay excursion
column3: The Pier itself was very busy on the day we visited. There is certainly plenty happening with rides, shops and food stalls of varying quality. I was a little underwhelmed but it was interesting to see and use as a starting point to walk along the wide expansive beaches to Venice beach and beyond. You can hire bikes from the pier and cover the area more quickly but we preferred to meander along and take in the sights and characters of the area.

Had a lovely walk from Venice beach to Santa Monica beach/pier lots of things and people to watch ,people on bikes skateboards and roller blades families friends enjoying the lovely evening. Ended up on the pier where my friends went on the roller coaster I was happy to watch.

I went there in the evening just to check out the ocean view, it was packed with kids, especially teens playing Pokemon Go. I, of course, played as well and found a bunch of Pokemons I have not yet seen here in Boston.

This is kind of a once you cross it off your list you don't go back. Nice to see it but extremely over crowded and kind of run down and trashy. Also, hang on to your kids .. One went missing while we were there. Easy to get lost in the chaos there.

column2: Assorrtment of Venues on Santa Monica Pier
column3: The first thing I saw was that 75% of the people on the pier were looking at their cell phones doing Pokeman Go! Bands played for tips, several seafood restaurants, carnival rides, and thousands of people on A Sunday afternoon. Don't forget to bring your kite(s) to fly on the beach. We flew 3.

I had been here before and sort of enjoyed it first time round.. Second time round I wasn't distract by the lights and that I had seen this place on movies. This time around I saw all the homeless people begging for money, the rubbish and the fact it was overcrowded and expensive with lots of crap for sale! Won't be going back ever again.

Debatably L.A.'s most notable landmark, although technically Santa Monica is a separate city. As a tour guide, it always pains me when folks want to drive up to the Hollywood sign ... a big waste of time. "Huge!" as Pretty Woman would say. More and more tourists are realizing Santa Monica is the place to be. Especially in summer when temperatures climb over a 100 degrees downtown and in the valley. Someone sang "Nobody walks in L.A." Wrong. I would advise you start at Wilshire Blvd. and 3rd street -- the north end of the Third Street Promenade and make your way 4 blocks south to Santa Monica Place. FYI the Promenade has some of the best street vendor performers, eateries and shopping. Santa Monica Place has all your high end retail, if you're into that and some awesome restaurants on the top level ... which now includes a new AMC dine-in movie theater. From there it's a short walk down to the pier where Forrest Gump turned around when he reached the west coast. The merry go ground will transport you back to your childhood as well as the iconic ferris wheel. It's also where Route 66 ends.

column2: Santa Monica Pier, the end for Route 66!
column3: It is exactly at the pier in Santa Monica that Route 66 ends! There is a historical plaque that ends the Route 66 which begins in Chicago, IL. One of the most visited places in California, with restaurants, shops, a beautiful beach and the last original Route 66 Store for you to buy souvenirs! Unmissable!

We had a lot of fun walking around muscle beach and seeing people do some incredible yoga and exercising on the beach equipment. Great pedestrian space for walking.The pier itself is pretty touristy with restaurants and an amusement park. We walked over to another area in Santa Monica right near the pier and there were some very nice shops, musicians playing and restaurants. A little less intense than right on the pier. Very reasonable parking fees at lots right before the pier on Main Street ($3 on a Monday).
Spent the day here it was a really delightful place to visit. The vibe of the area was fantastic. Beautiful weather beautiful beach

Santa Monica Pier is a great place if you enjoy crowds of people. I have been several times and the one thing that I try to do now is avoid the weekends! But this is a fun place to walk around and people watch.

It is always fun to stroll on the Santa Monica Pier at any time of the year, It is a perfect place to look at the waves, the scenery; to watch the people, the entertainers, people fishing off the pier, dogs, souvenir stands and shops, artist painting names on the grain of rice, taking a ride on many different available rides. Perfect picture spot.

It was great to take the family to this pier which is so easily recognizable from movies & tv. The rides and games are largely geared towards younger children, but we had fun on the roller coaster and enjoyed the view along the coastline.
A lovely old fashioned pier with plenty of charm. A lovely family atmosphere during the day. The kids caught lots of Pokemon while the adults enjoyed the view.
Great view of the beach from the pier. Tacky souvenir shops, cheap snacks, and old fashioned boardwalk games and rides.

Tulsa Time Day OneIt is 2:00 am in the city of Tulsa, Oklahoma and I know I am coming home. I fuel up the Mustang at the Quick Trip on South 49 West Avenue on the southwest side of Tulsa and I head out to the 44 freeway. It is still dark but that is just how I like it. I duck under the overpasses and pop out on the other side. The green sign says I-44W Oklahoma City with the arrow pointing left. https://www.google.com/maps/@36.0791165,-96.0492036,3a,75y,319.5h,82.42t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1srhqOIeXjR3yTHXg2W1785g!2e0!7i13312!8i6656Well I got to get going, the ramp is waiting. Like an airport runway the Mustang accelerates onto the freeway that quickly turns into Turner Turnpike and my speed picks up to 75 mph, Oklahoma City is on the horizon. Got to stop at the turnpike plaza near Stroud. I hand over a Lincoln and the worker hands me back a Washington. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.7712842,-96.6177653,3a,75y,242.43h,88.87t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1scoo76Og6th-9D7zVB808Bg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656Well the city is in the windshield so here we go.The OKC TransitHere we are at the end of the turnpike, I used those four Washington's pretty fast and I see yet another sign, I35S left lane, so here we go, by the way Def Leppard is on the stereo and its pumping fast. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.601128,-97.4158948,3a,75y,260.14h,94.81t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sOz63C-9x0XysSPu8tumyug!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 I slide on over for that little southbound push as the ramp is in sight. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.6000825,-97.4267076,3a,75y,298.83h,92.15t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s7dXyu333-34pIw_ZkNT29A!2e0!7i13312!8i6656. The southbound push has begun. The Mustang fires down the 35 freeway, no OHP or OKPD, good, that is good. In the distance I see yet another sign giving me yet another direction to go, I40W Amarillo left two lanes. Hmm okay, https://www.google.com/maps/@35.4743624,-97.4661853,3a,75y,187.23h,90.17t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sKINLc8rAdXcRNa7QF__s4Q!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 , here I go, a major westward push has begun. Heading west on the 40 I see exit 136 in Yukon so I duck in and top off, guess what folks I am at the point of no return, this is it. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.4883354,-97.7603439,3a,60y,287.5h,86.2t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1ssdUb7eFu7VNTcWbl1hqXbw!2e0!7i13312!8i6656Amarillo SunshineI get out of Yukon and really begin to stretch my legs, the Mustang is singing pretty good, Ms. Stevie is in the CD player, its 5:00 am, got my Coca Cola and everything is topped off. El Reno, Hydro, Weatherford, Clinton, Elk City, Sayre, Erick, and the little stop called Texola is in the rear view. I see the Texas Sign in the windshield, https://www.google.com/maps/@35.2270796,-100.0004929,3a,75y,262.1h,84.27t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sYlexj6mGOb957AfhubqMJQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Guess what, Amarillo 106 miles just down the road. Shamrock, McLean, Alanreed, and Groom are just a blur but wait, there is a big cross on the south side of the freeway so I guess I will stop and bow down and pray a bit. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.2126704,-101.11896,3a,60y,263.39h,86.39t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1szpPVe7_XRD66RUaDAa4LXA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Well Amarillo is waiting so I got to get going so away I go. I see the sun peeking out in the rear view and I see the Big Texan just down the way. Yes if you eat it in a hour with all the fixings its free or else you will soon regret it. The west Texas crossroads of the 27-40 is just down the freeway and alas I see yet another sign and it says I40W Albuquerque https://www.google.com/maps/@35.1925049,-101.8325089,3a,75y,268.68h,90t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s32lCDrAKmcSoHXDbYd3ZeA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Well time to bid Amarillo a due and get down the freeway.Watering TucumcariHeading west out of Amarillo the west Texas towns are getting to be mere wide spots, damn why not 80 mph, well lets get going. I wonder how many coats of paint those Cadillac's have on them there at the ranch. Well I don't know but nevertheless. Bushland, Wildorado, Vega, Adrian, and the wide spot Glenrio are just a memory as the Land of Enchantment is in sight. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.1827595,-103.0425867,3a,75y,274.76h,89.3t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sYQfCGzbVDklLIhRbp1drmA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 San Jon is a blur out the windshield and I will be watering Tucumcari in 19 miles so lets get going. The pace picks up to 75 mph, by the way I changed the CD to Rush back in Amarillo and then some Doobie Brothers, nice dichotomy of artist. There is the 1st Street exit 332 just ahead, a Shell station with a Subway is my best bet, time to water down Tucumcari and head down the freeway. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.1535434,-103.7248844,3a,75y,48.27h,77.92t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sKPcnuMDco0cNITJ2oVqXeg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656Sleepless in AlbuquerqueBack on the 40 just west of Tucumcari the sign says Albuquerque 162 miles, 80 mph is my best bet, hopefully no New Mexico troopers are out prowling around. Santa Rosa, Clines Corners, Moriarty, Edgewood, and Sedillo were nice but the Super 8 on Lliff Road is looking pretty good right now, need a nap. The freeway begins to spread out to a couple of more lanes and I see the central New Mexico crossroads just ahead. The sign over the freeway says I40W Gallup Left 3 Lanes. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.106679,-106.6107773,3a,75y,287.85h,92.75t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sNlFAUTx2-TIc3zgx7AH0og!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Yes another little slide to the left but this time its a gentle slide, not too bad so slide I go. Just across the Rio Grande the sign says Coors Road South and that is where I need to go. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.1062347,-106.6890156,3a,60y,268.95h,86.7t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s9Y4Eq5Ignf66fi5plwkN9g!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 South on Coors Road I see another Shell station, another top off and a Denny's for some travel grub https://www.google.com/maps/@35.1036607,-106.7057841,3a,63.7y,128.14h,79.28t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sNHGhS6KCxyncbLPIsA2PFA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 and I'm off to the motel for a nap. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.1033775,-106.7076303,3a,60y,214.52h,79.3t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sGMGHMRmfCsOpsULEF5gxYg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656The Winds of Winslow Day TwoEnnie Meanie Miny Moe, catch an entrance ramp by the toe, if it hollers let it pay, fifty dollars every day. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.1039613,-106.705465,3a,75y,11.32h,80.59t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sZeexKVvCiTiER5pGNf0x7w!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 did I see I40W Gallup puddy tat? I did, I really did! Lets go. Got some Queensryche in the CD player, its 2:00 am and just got caffeinated. I merge onto the freeway and head west out of Albuquerque after a six hour nap and back on my pony. The early morning desert air sure smells sweet, it is almost intoxicating. Gallup 130 miles just ahead. Grants makes way to Milan, then I arrive at the point where the water flow splits at the Continental Divide 7225 feet above sea level. Gallup, what Gallup, it was a blur in the windshield, either way it was still dark outside so lights were the only thing I could see. Itching to get out of New Mexico and cross into Arizona I finally see the state line, https://www.google.com/maps/@35.3632538,-109.046604,3a,75y,217.4h,92.15t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sc2sc9zdCG410molR5Yt4Dw!2e0!7i13312!8i6656Houck, Sanders and Chambers, three tiny desert towns in eastern Arizona look like relics of the past as I continue on my westward push to Winslow. Holbrook, and Joseph City dot the Little Colorado River just to the south of the freeway. Winslow is just ahead around 20 miles so got to keep going. I begin seeing names like Jackrabbit and other western names that sound more like a John Wayne movie or Bonanza than anything else but its all good. As I approach Winslow the sun begins to peek out and cast its light on the desert floor. The desert looks like its on fire and I begin to feel free as an eagle in flight. Crossing over the Little Colorado I have Winslow in sight.The Florist of FlagstaffJust out of Winslow I got the Eagles in the player, yeah takin' it easy down this good old interstate I see Canyon Diablo, at this point in the journey creeks and streams are little more than desert washes waiting on the monsoons for a fill up. Its around 7:00 am or so and the air is still cool and crisp with a little bit of a haze build-up in the distance. Twin Arrows is peering just outside the windshield of my pony, you can tell it actually has two arrows at n old abandoned trading post https://www.google.com/maps/@35.1618253,-111.2795058,3a,60y,211.07h,82.69t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sO9ht62ObsYgpQHASmMXxRA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 but I don't have time to look at them too much, the pony has been in full gallop for a few hours since I left Albuquerque at 2 this morning, so I get going. Into the distance I see yet another sign but it is the most important sign of the journey, the first sign indicating Los Angeles is ahead. Just went over Padre Canyon, Walnut Canyon, and now approaching Flagstaff. Yes the sign, the most important sign, https://www.google.com/maps/@35.2179708,-111.5774631,3a,75y,252.76h,77.98t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1slrZkUYN2vg3KMjCgk6BaBQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 and I know I am truly on my way back home. I see Exit 198 Butler Avenue just ahead, I think I will give my pony a rest while I fuel up. So I duck in and see a Chevron and Country Host Cafe. The food there is pretty good for this weary traveler. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.1921443,-111.624423,3a,60y,204.78h,81.07t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s_hcYLlJgTu4tKHn6m-ISFQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 I get the pony all cleaned up, watered and do a check out and head on out.Needles StationHeading out of Flagstaff I see the northern Arizona crossroads of 40-17 just ahead. You guessed right Los Angeles left lanes so slide the pony over once more. I pop out the other side of the interchange and see my first control sign for good old L.A. Los Angeles 492 miles and here I go. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.177874,-111.6760092,3a,60y,283.88h,87.79t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sc-GFeMetHgN8uTIfUo2HWQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 The pony begins running through Williams, then Ash Fork, and after that Seligman comes into view. As the pony leaves Seligman the road gets rugged and rocky but beautiful. I love the American southwest, its rugged but the most beautiful in the world to me. Exit 71 U.S 93, very last chance to head back east but I've gone too far to turn back now. https://www.google.com/maps/@35.1593782,-113.6960471,3a,75y,258.06h,91.86t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sTRYBVyfeCNP_J5ft3zcZKw!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 This pony needs to get going, time to begin finding the magic river. Did I mention Kingman, well now I did. I see my first In and Out, the fry daddy there makes a killer fry, well enough of that for now. Got to blow through this town Needles is still waiting on my presence. Go through this little pass and start heading due south. Yucca on the right and the Arizona Death Star on the left, https://www.google.com/maps/@34.8614806,-114.1471153,3a,75y,178.32h,94.05t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sH5K1sJ7khtK4ztFycxyCDg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Well that was interesting time to get going. The freeway begins its gentle swing to the right as I feel the final push. Yes I am beginning to catch whiffs of that familiar sweet Mojave desert air as the mile markers begin to count down. The final westward push has begun. Exit 9 AZ 95 is a blur, then Exit 2, its all downhill for there. For a moment I am thinking I am on planet Mars and the pony is the rover searching for substance in this vast desert. Hmm what do we have here, Exit 1 Golden Shores /Oatman, nice little western town but that will have to wait. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.7184438,-114.4732131,3a,59.8y,264.09h,90.77t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s6eEeGaf4HwZmhWDo3DGWJQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 With the water tower to the right and the natural gas/utility bridge to the left, the bridge approach is clearly in sight, yes the magic river, the Colorado, that lonesome snake that winds itself though this desert, and a supplier of life for the desert. Alas my pony's hooves touch the bridge in full gallop, goodbye Arizona, nice knowing you and that sign we have been looking for is there, right there for all the world to see. Welcome to California/San Bernardino County Line, So-Cal at last. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.7170933,-114.4903191,3a,75y,279.89h,92.68t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s_k1_lzS9v-8UKcZ55MG9pQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Next stop is the inspection station https://www.google.com/maps/@34.7525682,-114.5653703,3a,75y,320.32h,82.65t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sB2UwnWV6l4JiQJmP_4MbhQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 and then on to Needles. We gallop on to Needles, as we see Exit 142, J Street, guess what you better stop right there before the Great Barrier, https://www.google.com/maps/@34.8358356,-114.6091141,3a,75y,325.82h,92.77t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1slMaMZh2WxYBlr5Q_vXV7KQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Here at Needles Station is the J Street Gas Station and across the way is that familiar Jack in the Box. Better get the pony fed and watered now and I better top off myself. By the way pack some supplies while you are here, the desert is hot, unprepared and you don't stand a chance. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.840057,-114.6108284,3a,62.5y,74.9h,82.76t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s-StGEzqAtops7W0xZPcV9w!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Check the pony's shoes too, can't have them wearing out, the desert will eat them.Needles-Barstow The Great BarrierSwitching on some Robert Plant, the CD Principle of Moments with everything topped off time to conquer the Great Barrier the Mojave Desert. There isn't anything between Needles and Barstow except Ludlow so here we go. Its getting into early afternoon and I can begin to feel the heat rising on the desert floor. Just passed the Vegas/Searchlight turn-off US 95 https://www.google.com/maps/@34.8792623,-114.7500071,3a,75y,253.1h,91.59t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sjRqa6toCS7O_Z-hOKMDiuQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 then Water Road. There is a substation off to the left, Mountain Springs Road at the summit, then Goffs/Essex Road. The BNSF railroad snaking under the freeway. A bit farther down the freeway Kelbaker Road comes into view. The pony is in full gallop and not CHP in sight, good that is good. Yes good old Ludlow, just a wide spot in this vast desert but I'm not stopping there. Whats that, oh okay it was only Newberry Springs, wide spot, wide spot, wide spot. I'm beginning to look for some civilization at this point but finally I'm saved by Daggett. The Barstow-Daggett Airport looms off to the right. Finally seeing the exit numbers dwindle down. Exit 7 will buy you a whiskey in Daggett but I don't drink, then we see Exit 1, East Main Street, Barstow California, only 5,280 feet from the end of I40W. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.8856366,-116.9891765,3a,75y,269.93h,87.04t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sfaNUf9hDzEqAzvb8WEXzqg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 This freeway is winding down as it passes over the 15 and I see the very end as it passes under Muriel Drive overpass. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.8862786,-117.011602,3a,60y,267.85h,98.16t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s0BORW6Yvm6MAlSEq298whQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 I merge onto the 15 and bid the 40 a due, see ya in my rearview. As the 15 sweeps through Barstow I see yet another interchange the 15-CA 58 that goes towards Bakersfield but no I'm not going there, the sign says I15S San Bernardino left three lanes, so lets hit it. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.8758596,-117.0708926,3a,27.2y,223.46h,92.29t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sIDb5g1Xw1KVa-CtwdUUGlQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 I jet passed the interchange and head to Lenwood Road, and one more top off at the TA Truck Stop. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.8543483,-117.0879741,3a,75y,262.26h,82.11t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sFl_fjojTpA3uPK0Ab08xaQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Yay I conquered the Great Barrier.Eating Spaghetti in the Inland EmpireBefore I get back on my pony, I take a walk out next to the fence close to the 15 and take a deep refreshing breath of desert air, and yes I ponder. One womyn, one pony, and a big wide freeway, and I ponder. Well lets go, the Empire awaits. One look at the ramp and its time turn on some serious Def Leppard and get going. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.8541634,-117.0876613,3a,60y,116.21h,90.55t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sBP2mIfaYWE0M_slaD-Qhgg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Time to rock-n-roll this freeway needs some hot sauce and I prefer chipotle with hot peppers, can we say no CHP, yes we most certainly can. My mustang needs a good stretching out. I jet out to the 15 freeway looking for Victorville and Hesperia, twin cities in the High Mojave. Getting past Hesperia I see the San Bernardino Mountains just in the distance. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.3446998,-117.4550532,3a,75y,244.7h,90.05t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sxpxkItBlTTOf_MNtf8EUsQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Cajon wants to eat me but I won't let it, good tip here, center lane, 70 mph, and let it float down the pass, don't try to get cute or force it or you will pay 50 dollars everyday. Here we go. A gentle glide down the pass. Recently the 15-215 interchange has been reconfigured for big trucks so I would watch the signs, so be very careful there, caution.https://www.google.com/maps/@34.2399684,-117.429954,3a,75y,130.89h,82.91t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sCwRwumNtRUp6STwlhPSCsA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656Just past the split I see the massive cityscape emerge from the wilderness, and yes I know I am on my way home now. Just past Falcon Ridge there on Beech the 15-210 interchange cones into view. Right turn towards Pasadena, left toward San Bernardino-Redlands, straight through to San Diego, but I do know where I'm going, this is So-Cal and I am in my element. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.1460066,-117.4846292,3a,57.1y,229.15h,85.03t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sqnJS9bFnUAmAtf-xF430Hg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Gotta keep going. Just past Fourth Street and nestled on the northwest corner of the 15-10 interchange Ontario Mall sits there greeting me, and alas my home interchange says come on down you are the next contestant on the Price is Right. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0739932,-117.5449948,3a,75y,184.63h,85.97t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1scnimE4YLe74akDFVoqCsow!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Hmm good spaghetti, I love Italian.Empires to AngelesPushing west on the 10 freeway the view of the Empire is looking mighty sweet, just a tad bit to go but I'm finally getting there. The wall on the S. Mills overpass tells me I am finally bidding San Bernardino County a due as I enter Claremont and Los Angeles County, finally I am back in my home county so lets keep pushing, push push push. The "Stang is at full gallop and she ain't stopping now. I feel the rhythm of the freeway, I hear her song. Just past Fairplex and the 57 Freeway in Pomona the San Gabriel valley presents itself to me, I am a native of the Valley, Birthplace Monterey Park, my first home in Alhambra. As I descend into the Valley (tip 70 mph center lane and float all the way into Covina and West Covina and you will be fine). Just past the 605 I am getting into El Monte and then Rosemead. Just past there I find my cradle, Monterey Park on the left, Alhambra to my right. Back in my hometowns, but the pier is just a few minutes more down the road. Just ahead the 710 is in view. There is a back story to that freeway. There are talks in the works to connect the 710 to Long Beech Freeway extension just off the 210 in Pasadena up north via a tunnel, lots of digging there. I pop out the other side of the interchange jet under the two pedestrian walkways and just past the second walkway I see the sign I have been looking for since Flagstaff, Los Angeles City Limits https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0555969,-118.1955378,3a,40.5y,276.91h,80.87t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sBYW28393v3unYHk6h80-hQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 and her sky scrapers are in sight. As I slide on over to the right I enter the second to the last phase of the journey as I see the signs pointing to Santa Monica begin to appear, so lets go the Pier awaits. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0553561,-118.2002313,3a,75y,254.68h,88.8t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sdaWTUrMyBrbDzRy7xXW8ag!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 And I am going here, https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0562779,-118.213419,3a,75y,262.49h,94.97t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sZ6RD831lowOJesDznElgMA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 And the very last push into the city is here, https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0373884,-118.2201938,3a,63.4y,197.43h,98.98t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sW9TwkEOC1ZoVEyA1EIBkBA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Finally, finally, finally.Breaker 99.5 KLOS I Hear You Loud and ClearOver the L.A River and into the woods I feel the beat of the city, she calls me to her bosom. My 'Stang isn't quitting now, the 110 is in view as KLOS is belting out those all too familiar tunes, they have the Lep coming out of that 100,000 watt tower of power, To the right is downtown and the House that Kobe Built, nestled in the northeast corner of the interchange https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0364209,-118.269858,3a,85.7y,304.91h,95.08t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sVAHF748Xv5tv7ReV8f8D9A!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 The Lep is still pumping out of the 100,000 watt mega-house at KLOS, and I'm feeling pretty damn good about myself as I push west on the 10. Just past Exit 7B and to the left I see three towers but it is the center one that Is pumping out the KLOS power tunes, https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0345949,-118.3660176,3a,75y,251.17h,88.33t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sjPQzCCF_SeraA5EgQUyTpQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 and I'm Lovin' Every Minute of It. Still pushing, gotta keep pushing. Just past the Overland Avenue exit I see the beginnings of the final interchange take shape, yes it is the 10-405 interchange. North on the 405 and you are in San Fernando, south you are heading to LAX, straight through and Santa Monica is straight ahead. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0318182,-118.4146718,3a,75y,273.51h,90.37t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sZ7QU00k4F1cQHLhX0E1SAA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 The D.J's at KLOS are mad scientist of the radio world and always keeps the ticker going, I think its in the sauce, extra spicy I like it. There is a back story to the 405, the Angelinos called it Carmageddon. They shut down the freeway so they could work on the overpasses up around the Mulholland-Skiball area, H.O.V lanes are equally worthless but that is our friendly neighborhood CAL-TRANS for ya. Well lets go once again, gotta get past the 405 to the promise land. As I approach the Lincoln Boulevard overpass Exit 1A finally sews this dress up in a nice neat package as the 10 Freeway comes to it climatic conclusion. This 2,460.34 mile interstate has its beginnings in Jacksonville Florida at the 95-10 interchange west of the St. Johns River. This mighty interstate runs through the southern part of the United States. It runs through the states of Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and California and one of the longest in the country. I have traveled through the states of Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and last but not certainly the least my home state of California. I've taken Interstates 44, 35, 40, 15, and the 10 to get to this point and now I am looking at the finish line right here. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0151423,-118.4854993,3a,60y,226.88h,90t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sCyICvP444WxPiKfSewDLhQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656Doin' The S's Just Down The StreetAs I slide on over to the far right lane to 5th Street in merry ole Santa Monica the mad scientist at KLOS switches over to some Doobies and Steely Dan, the 'Stang begins to slow her gallop. She did good, really, really good on those monster trails, and its about time for her to get some shut eye. Taking Exit 1A onto 5th Street, https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0144357,-118.4867965,3a,75y,221.32h,84.98t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sUGBrtDQxQ655a9LrTEF-Qw!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 it turns sharply right, https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0131527,-118.4894597,3a,60.9y,287.45h,81.95t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s8jxTZSpwmQSrAl2BbmY1Wg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 I am needing a bit of that Santa Monica Boulevard just ahead. The left turn lane is your best bet. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0170283,-118.4940441,3a,75y,319.82h,80.47t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sd55gZG_i7OjKelF4C3nLpQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 I see the Union Bank Building on the northwest corner of 5th and Santa Monica Boulevard. Hmm Sheryl Crow has a song with that in it. Find it on ITunes. Heading west on Santa Monica Boulevard the 'Stang slows to a nice relaxing walk as I look around for a bit. This is also getting to the end of Route 66. Route 66 west begins in Chicago on S. Michigan and E. Adams in front of The Art Institute of Chicago, and begins its westward trek through the states of Illinois, Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and California. It was the Mother Road. Large sections of the famous route have been restored, but others are still either taken up by our current interstate system or have fallen into terrible disrepair. As I keep on going further west on Route 66 (Santa Monica Boulevard), the 3rd Street Promenade looms large. Nice quaint shops and some more famous names are there. It is just like an outdoor walking mall, quintessentially southern California.https://www.google.com/maps/@34.015276,-118.4963267,3a,75y,204.5h,79.81t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sGgYEf8K0mAqmqAbu2uVs3Q!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Further west Ocean Boulevard comes into view and just passed that the Mother of Us All is in full view. The palms of Santa Monica are especially pretty at sunset on a nice spring evening I would say. Yes the left lane is your best bet so here we go. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0143194,-118.4977473,3a,75y,204.72h,85.22t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s6XNdvR-xMDOe-08x1o4pcw!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 As I make that left turn onto Ocean Boulevard the palms look so pretty as I get my first good look to my right at the Mighty Pacific Ocean. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0131583,-118.4969965,3a,75y,196.71h,85.51t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sIZz_KQpwD-HEhu9701ELVQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 Further to the south I see the Santa Monica Pier entrance begin to come into view, right on the end of Colorado Avenue. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0115401,-118.4950573,3a,75y,167.87h,89.08t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1snekn4tqeYjbnexCbb40sdA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 As I make that last right turn onto the Pier overpass https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0113094,-118.4950391,3a,75y,219.59h,87.52t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sDNpA8N13uqLzBJQErPw6Cg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 I then make that last left turn just past Rusty's Surf Ranch pay the parking fee ($15.00), tie the 'Stang up and I am finally here. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0096774,-118.4963957,3a,75y,348.44h,84.05t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s6iGEWyOQC5-SH9-qEdMoZg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656Walking on the Wild SideAs I stroll down to the end of the Pier I stop by Harbor Grill for a quick bite https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0087441,-118.4981668,3a,45.3y,113.88h,84.12t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sEzvqw6q2_8_gXhwtUUyZpQ!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 All that driving has me a bit hungry but those pesky pigeons and sea gulls are always wanting to dive bomb my plate for some free grub. I finish up here with my large Coca Cola in my hand and stroll on down past Pacific Park. Nice wheel and coaster they have there. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0086921,-118.4982308,3a,75y,144.46h,90.91t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s5AgcEelSaZnJOtXlC3e02g!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 I'll do the wheel after I digest that whopper of a burger I just ate. I stroll down a bit further and go through the Harbor Office tunnel out to the end of the Pier, Maria Sol to the right and the Harbor Office to the left, https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0077586,-118.4994396,3a,89.3y,225.19h,77.53t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sUGsCIygN4icNVQ5Te4tpCw!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 I stroll a bit further and yes I see the Santa Monica Pier Bait and Tackle on my left just below the Harbor Office, https://www.google.com/maps/@34.007535,-118.4996901,3a,75y,135.74h,85.51t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sEVq7Va_Ymm4jZ5Q2QnZMfw!2e0!7i13312!8i6656The ArrivalAs I stroll just a bit further I see my favorite spot in the whole world, right on the northwest corner of the upper Pier deck. It has a plaque that says when the Pier was dedicated. I see the beach and the Santa Monica Mountains to my right and straight ahead is nothing but the Mother of Us All, my Hannah, it is there that I have finally arrived and I am at peace. https://www.google.com/maps/@34.0075703,-118.5000694,3a,75y,245.99h,78.74t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sWIlB2EzXWafZiP2i-aBPOg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656End of Day TwoPrologueI have taken this trip, the most beautiful vistas, quirky shops and stop overs, the vastness of the Mojave, and the seemingly endless ribbon of road. I have seen the Mounts of the San Bernardino Forest, and have braved the pass of Cajon (San Andreas Fault Zone). This is my home pier, my home beach, and it is here I receive my healing. Thank you for listening. Peace to you all to all a good trip and good day. Thank you. Peace to all the world. Good Afternoon.
Rides are over priced, the pier is small and crowded. Obviously a land mark and tourist attraction, but that is about it.
I always love to visit this place when in the LA area. It's great for couples and families. Fun rides and interesting people
This was part of my Grandson's graduation trip. It was a bit of a drive from Park Plaza Lodge but it was so worth it. Ate lunch and walked around listening to the music and taking in the sites.
I'd been to LA before but had never been here! This is the iconic end to the famous Route 66 and has a tremendous view of Santa Monica and the beach. Wow! Great way to spend an afternoon!!

Walked the beaches from Venice to the Santa Monica pier, lots of vendors and things to buy. The pier has a Ferris wheel and a small "roller coaster". There is a lot of dinning in the area so you have ur choice of what every u want. Weather was not too hot but beware on the hot days u will get burned. Great place to just take in the LA scene. Bring water of u decide to walk the whole beach and uber back. Parking is not a win win on this but uber is!
